posts.cooked:
Hoping to get a factual answer to this question.
Someone posted on LinkedIn that Apple AI is reading Signal messages by default; however, I want to avoid the trap of ‚Äòif the Internet says so, it must be true‚Äô (Jeff Jockisch on LinkedIn: #signal #apple #privacy #securecomms #securemessaging | 49 comments)
In fact, the person followed up his post with ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have proof Apple is scanning in-app Signal messages.‚Äù
So, I‚Äôm hoping to hear an answer on this topic that‚Äôs based in fact (not a guess). Thanks!

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Signal data is partitioned away from the rest of the phone data, so it can‚Äôt be read by or used to train Apple Intelligence.

As an aside, LinkedIn is the last place I‚Äôd be trusting to find factual information. It‚Äôs almost all bots and scams. Always check multiple sources when claims of any kind are made anywhere.

Avitus:

Signal data is partitioned away from the rest of the phone data, so it can‚Äôt be read by or used to train Apple Intelligence.

Are you referring to the app being sandboxed? That wouldn‚Äôt stop Apple Intelligence from reading the content of the app. I believe Apple Intelligence does use apps‚Äô data to enrich its features, after all even when not using it, Siri suggestion offer to send messages to frequently contacted Signal users, so seems reasonable that the AI may read that.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Contextual assumptions and AI training are two different things. The AI is not being trained on Signal messages. Siri is likely pulling data from actions taken outside of Signal e.g. sharing a picture from Instagram or the Messages app. And if you‚Äôve had an iPhone for years, that‚Äôs years of behavioral data informing the contextual assumptions. But as I said:

Avitus:

Always check multiple sources when claims of any kind are made anywhere.
I am no expert on AI integration nor iOS, but I would assume that keyboard input and notification content could be used even if information within the Signal database is protected.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

notification content

Signal message content is not exposed to Android or iOS in push notifications. This was addressed almost a year ago:

Mastodon ‚Äì 11 Dec 23

Meredith Whittaker (@Mer__edith@mastodon.world)

In Signal, push notifications simply act as a ping that tells the app to wake up. They don't reveal who sent the message or who is calling (not to Apple, Google, or anyone). Notifications are processed entirely on your device. This is different from...

link_counts.title: Meredith Whittaker: "In Signal, push notifications simply act as a pin‚Ä¶" - Mastodon

posts.cooked: Not push notifications, the notifications that pop up on your screen or are shared to wearables, etc. Each user can set these (at least in Android) to hide everything or show parts. If parts are shown to the system, then anything with the appropriate privilege can read and use the content.

posts.name: (he/him)
posts.cooked: they‚Äôre not exposed to push notification providers, i.e. Apple and Google, but the OS can still access them. I can still set e.g. a Tasker task based on the content of the notification.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

Not push notifications, the notifications that pop up on your screen or are shared to wearables, etc.

Those are push notifications.

CueHD:

then anything with the appropriate privilege can read and use the content.

Right. If you explicitly grant access then it is readable. It is not readable by default.

posts.name: Fabian
posts.cooked:
Push notifications can be triggered remote and locally as @Avitus already mentioned.
Flutter for example calls locally triggered notifications local notifications. The OS can be involved, depending on how the implementation is done. AFAIK you can provide notifications without the OS being able to see the contents of said message. (Could be wrong, still learning app development for my university)

Avitus:

Those are push notifications.

‚ÄúPush notifications‚Äù is not specific enough. Here are the two types being discussed:

1: The notifications sent from Signal server via Google or Apple cloud messaging. These can not be manually turned off (in the official client). As @Avitus mentioned above, message content is not sent by Signal in these messages. I was not referring to these.

2: The notification popup that the Signal client displays on one‚Äôs device. These can be turned off completely or adjusted so that only certain information is contained within the popup. Information contained in these popup notifications can be scraped by any process that has the permission to do so.

Thanks all, I appreciate the comments!

And I‚Äôll attempt to clarify what I‚Äôm hearing so far. Please correct/add/modify anything as needed.

Signal message data:

  • Signal message data is partitioned away from the rest of the phone data, so it can‚Äôt be read by or used to train Apple Intelligence.
  • Signal message content can be exposed to Android or iOS in notification popups that the Signal client displays on one‚Äôs device, depending on how that option is configured in Signal
  • Siri can pull data from actions taken outside of Signal e.g. sharing a picture from Instagram or the Messages app
  • Keyboard input in Signal can be read by iOS or Android

Signal notifications:

  • Notification content can be read by Android or iOS
  • Notifications sent from Signal server via Google or Apple cloud messaging cannot not be manually turned off (in the official client), but message content is not sent by Signal in these messages
  • Notification popups that the Signal client displays on one‚Äôs device can be turned off completely or adjusted so that only certain information is contained within the popup. Information contained in these popup notifications can be scraped by any process that has the permission to do so.

Options that be configured:

  • For controlling the content of Signal notifications, you can configure Signal to show ‚ÄòName and message‚Äô, ‚ÄòName only‚Äô, or ‚ÄòNo name or message‚Äô (in Signal ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Notifications ‚Üí Show)
  • Incognito keyboard setting: Signal uses the existing keyboard or Input Method Editor (IME) on your device. On some Android devices, you can turn on Incognito Keyboard to enable an optional keyboard privacy flag that is provided by the Android operating system. NOTE - Keyboards and IME‚Äôs can ignore Android‚Äôs Incognito Keyboard flag, which means this Android system flag is a best effort, not a guarantee.

That was a very well written summary.

I would add that a privacy-respecting keyboard is likely better than the incognito mode of the regular keyboard.

bpdehn:

Signal message data is partitioned away from the rest of the phone data, so it can‚Äôt be read by or used to train Apple Intelligence.

This is meant to protect the app from other apps and the OS from the app. It‚Äôs a standard iOS/Android feature that cannot protect the app from the OS. The OS makes the rules so Apple Intelligence in practice COULD read any data from Signal if it wanted to. It does not mean it does.

The other bullet points become irrelevant due to this. For example message content in not sent over the network but on the device itself the data is pulled from the server, then decrypted to locally generate a notification, which can also be read by Apple Intelligence in principle, like everything else on the system.

posts.name: elcapitan
posts.cooked: Go to iOS Settings ‚Üí Apple Intelligence and Siri ‚Üí find Signal in Applications-> turn off all Settings including ‚ÄúLearn from this app‚Äù

posts.name: Marianne
posts.cooked: You can and should simply disable Apple Intelligence for privacy!

posts.name: Bapt Eash
posts.cooked: Don‚Äôt you worry, everything that gets displayed on your screen is used.
